22 The Jeake Family of Rye, 1640-1736

A close relationship between the two prior to the disagreement is indicated not only by the exchange of a token but also by Richard’s intimate knowledge of Barbara's previous relationships. In his letters he made several mentions of her second husband, Mr Harding, and demonstrated an awareness that Barbara had already married twice against her will (FRE 5270). The intimacy of the relationship in also indicated by the promise of ‘letters full of kisses’ and Richard’s desire to ‘injoy thee one night instead of every nights dreames on thee’ (FRE 5269). The question of whether this indicates an already physical relationship is problematic but it was certainly not unusual for engaged couples to become physically intimate.* Another clue to Barbara and Richard's relationship is his claimed affection for her young daughter, Bab. Barbara had left Rye during their quarrel and Bab was being cared for by a local woman. Richard visited her on at least one occasion so that he ‘might kisse mine owne’ (FRE 5270). No other indications about Richard’s connection with Bab are given in the letters making this tantalising phrase impossible to interpret but the fact that Richard felt able to visit the child must indicate an already close relationship.

Richard’s letters are equally interesting because they expose the nature of his, not unjustified, doubts about the relationship. Fletcher argues that men were expected to take an assertive role in early modern courtships but, even without the quarrel, there Was a serious impediment to Richard’s dominance of the relationship.”* Notably, he claimed that he was ‘not borne to a great inheritance’ and could offer only ‘love and poverty’ (FRE 5269). Richard obviously feared that Barbara saw him as a poor eco- nomic prospect as he questioned whether ‘A better fortune make a lesser love far more worthy in thy eyes’ (FRE 5269). Barbara’s anger over the exposure of the watch sub- jected Richard to additional doubts. He doubted her love, accused her of picking a quarrel about the watch on purpose to end the relationship and expressed jealousy

bout the prospect that Barbara might have other suitors (FRE 5268 and 5270). Although Richard was eloquent in his pleadings on his own behalf he also nployed what we might now describe as emotional blackmail to convince Barbara to eturn home in his use of little Bab’s crying for her ‘moda, moda, moda [mother, mother, mother]’ (FRE 5269). Moreover, he threatened both the judgment of god and society against Barbara’s behaviour. He reminded her: ‘my Love there will be atime of searching, all the secrets of our hearts, no covers nor pretences can cloake us from the all seeing eye of God’. Equally, he asked her ‘consider how many have been ruined by breaking their engaged faith’ (FRE 5269). Unfortunately, the surviving letters do not tell us which of Richard’s arguments persuaded Barbara to accept his suit but the couple did marry. There is also no record of whether Barbara’s third and final mar- riage was a happy one. Although Barbara will appear regularly in the chapters to fol- low, Richard has left few traces in the records,
